Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Device-Based Therapies for Hypertension Management

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults with resistant hypertension, recruited from multiple clinical centers.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received catheter-based renal denervation (RDN), while the control group received standard antihypertensive medication.

Objective.evidence: To assess the effectiveness of RDN in reducing blood pressure compared to standard treatment.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in systolic blood pressure (SBP) over six months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the RDN group and 100 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the RDN group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The RDN group showed a significant reduction in SBP (mean difference = 5.2 mm Hg, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the RDN group and 1% in the control group experiencing side effects.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
